log.text: Risk management is how you survive and build longevity in trading.
If you’re not comfortable losing money consistently, this isn’t for you.
Limit the number of trades you take—the more frequency, the more likely you're gonna lose.
If you can’t cover small ends consistently, you won’t handle big leverage.
Rushing to profit is the surest, fastest way to lose money.
Control the amount of money you put up—and control yourself.
Study what led to you being wrong so you can stop falling victim to it.
Before pulling the trigger, confirm there’s enough range to profit.
Be patient with drawdown recovery—don’t try to get it back in one trade.
Be more disciplined—the discipline will keep you rooted in sober thinking.
Practical beats performative.
Panic and fear of missing out will make you act impulsively—stick to the rules.
Use your journal for positive, constructive notes—no toxic thinking.
Losses are normal—control them; over time you’ll make more money than you lose.
You can’t force price to do what you want—you can only align with it.
Align seasonal tendency, quarterly shift, and monthly bias with a weekly profile.
Be willing to lose—and lose a lot—early on. It's part of it.
You don’t get good at big leverage by funding bigger; you condition yourself over time with little.
Don’t have it in your mindset you have to take a lot of trades every single day.
A structured monthly target turns randomness into progress.
Measured moves matter: replicate prior swings to anticipate distance.
When ends are already met, you won’t be impulsive with your retail account.
Scale profits—and learn how to make money even when you’re wrong.
An eight-loss streak is absolutely realistic; be prepared for it.
Avoid chasing parabolic equity surges.
TradingView, demo platforms, and back-testing tools are for building habits—not gambling.
Adding more money after a bad week isn’t the answer—discipline is.
Losses are part of the business transactions in this industry.
Trend, reversal, or consolidation—your market profile frames every decision.
If you don't have the understanding of liquidity, your trading is going to suffer from it.
Strip the chart down and focus on the four price levels: the open, the high, the low, and the close.
Don't measure yourself against someone else.
When am I ready for live funds? It begins with proof of concept.
Weekly ‘power of three’: accumulate below the open, manipulate around it, distribute away from it.
When you have income streams, confidence doesn’t translate into over-leveraged trading.
Use time and price together: act when your level and the kill zone line up.
There is no perfect trader and no perfect system—losses are part of this business.
We’re not trying to predict the reaction to the news—we wait for it to hit.
It’s not about being right—it’s about being aligned with the order flow.
Smart money concepts are not going to die out.
Multiple losses do not prove your method is broken.
Order blocks can offer high-accuracy, low-drawdown entries.
Trading without stops will make you lose money faster.
The highest-probability trades align with the higher-timeframe direction.
I hate losing—but I reduce risk after a loss instead of swinging harder.
Trading above the weekly open in a bearish week = overbought. Trading below the open in a bullish week = oversold.
Institutions hunt counterparties—orders resting above highs and below lows.
We’re not gambling—we’re hunting high-probability scenarios.
Zero heat entries come from planning, not luck.
Ends must meet—but don’t take fear about your ends into the marketplace.
Don’t rush profits; keep the monthly return as the focus.
5% risk is absolutely too much—it’s insane. Don’t do it.
Don’t blow your account because you can’t accept that you were wrong.
For beginners, short-term or day trading gives the most useful feedback; skip scalping at first.
Wait for the market to show its hand—then trade with it.
Ask: where would everyone else’s trade idea fail?
Give yourself permission to be wrong and allow yourself to grow.
Build mini study journal cases—not live trades with real money.
Funded margin isn’t psychological readiness.
Set realistic timelines—or you rush to destruction.
Look past the image lifestyle.
We start arm-wrestling the market because we want to be right—that’s how accounts die.
Wait for most, not all, of your tools to align, then act.
Price never moves in a straight line; it swings, consolidates, and swings again.
You don’t need perfection to be profitable; pursue alignment with order flow.
Avoid looking for hot-hand gurus.
Use three timeframes per style: position (monthly/weekly/daily), swing (daily/4h/1h), short-term (4h/1h/15m), day (1h/15m/5m).
Stop pretending to be somebody you’re not and do the work.
Keep your trading controlled to keep your emotions controlled.
Monthly highs and lows, weekly highs and lows, daily highs and lows, and finally session highs and lows.
Learn to read the charts and business opportunities open—bringing business income.
Between entry and target lies the gray area—get comfortable living there.
Taking partials reduces risk while paying you.
Let the highest timeframe show where price is reaching; time entries with the mid and low frames.
Formulate everything you’re doing to get in sync with the monthly bias.
You only need to find one setup and then be done for the day.
Focus on previous day’s highs and lows, previous week’s highs and lows, previous month’s highs and lows.
The algorithm seeks sell-side liquidity below old lows and buy-side liquidity above old highs.
Cast forth a vision: where are you going, what’s your objective, what’s your goal?
Pre-plan your exit before the expansion begins; don’t negotiate with a fast market after it’s moving.
Control risk first; profits come later.
Before year six you’re a wild cowboy; after, you know exactly what you’re looking for.
Don't count other people's money.
Guard your mind.
Outline when you want to buy and when you want to go short—put it on paper.
Learn to locate high-probability liquidity pools.
Binge-watching charts grooms you as a gambler.
The first six years of my trading development are plagued with everything you could have possibly done wrong.
Project targets with measured swings and legs—and exit before the exact objective.
Trading is absolutely a unique solo sport.
Small capital to secure a funded account beats depositing $10,000 you might blow.
Weekly bias 101: in bullish conditions, the low of the week usually forms between Sunday’s open and Wednesday’s New York open.
Time of day, in concert with bias, puts you in the highest order of probability.
Approach your life as a business and run your life as a business.
Build plateaus in equity by scaling down after losses, then scaling back up.
Remember this: to and through.
Stick to what you were trying to do: scale out, hit your target, move to the sidelines.
Power of Three: accumulation, manipulation, distribution—day after day.
Employment income is static—limited to what your employer feels you’re worth.
Every model loses—you’re going to have to accept that.
Appreciate the percentage over the dollar gain or loss.
Vision first, process next, lifestyle last.
No one will control your risk for you—not your spouse, not your broker. It must be in your plan.
If you don’t believe it’s possible for you, nothing you learn will help you.
OTE: the classic 62%–70.5% retracement is a powerful framework.
Price is fractal—the same formations repeat on every timeframe.
Controlling risk is more important than the entry signal or the exit.
The chart reflects your life pressures unless you control them.
You’re not only trading with money—you’re trading with mental capital.
Daily highs and lows offer the potential for draws on liquidity—buy stops above, sell stops below.
Above equal highs sit buy stops; below equal lows sit sell stops.
I’m not here to look smart—I got into this to make money and not work the rest of my life.
Your wins are your wins; your losses are your losses—own them.
Only consider trading for a living when you’re properly funded—about $100,000 or more.
Treat losses like normal life setbacks, not grand catastrophes.
Be content with enough.
Plot the Sunday opening price across the whole week—then let the market tell you overbought/oversold without indicators.
Reduce leverage when taking losses.
Stop worrying about the money—scared money makes no money.
You have to seek your own approval by your own study and your own development.
Don't change trading approaches—stick to one method and master it.
Stay with one framework and build a large sample set before you touch live funds.
You’re not trying to go against momentum—you’re trying to get in sync with institutional order flow.
Preserve capital first; preserve mental capital always.
Recognition comes from study; you'll recognize it as it forms.
When structure shifts, expect retracements—use them for new entries.
Your friends are only going to be interested once you start making money.
Decide who you are—position trader, swing trader, short-term, day trader, or scalper—before you decide what to do.
Can you build wealth in trading? Absolutely—but nobody starts there.
Below the weekly open is where smart money accumulates when the higher time frame is bullish.
Off days and holidays: pour that time into your family.
Measure entry to target time, drawdown, and how long the trade took.
You cannot allow monthly ends to plague your decision making in trading.
You have to pursue this on your own steam, your own energy.
Perfection isn’t required; discipline is.
You don't have to rush—especially if you're younger than thirty.
Most fair value gaps will not completely close on re-delivery of price.
Peace of mind and financial solitude are better than image.
Whatever you offer the market with open palms, it will take.
List out all of your monthly ends—the bills you have to make every single month—and trim what’s not essential.
Find your unique model and grow from it.
Demo is not live—it's a different world.
Don't go to work and tell your co-workers that you're going to be quitting your job soon.
Think like a business owner, not a gambler.
If you chose this path, it needs to be second only to family.
Profitability beats being ‘right’ every time.
Don't change strategies while you're in a trade.
Make ends meet first; grow from there.
You are not expected to be in every possible trade idea or price swing.
Run your life like a business.
Learn to limit trade frequency.
Invite the possibility of being wrong—perfection will always evade you.
London open often sets the high or low; New York continues—unless a key level forces reversal.
You’re investing in yourself with a plan of action.
You will lose fortunes—expect the pain; it won’t kill you.
Protect your access to the funded account—follow the rules.
Context + liquidity + timing = a predictable scalp.
Price action models are useless to anyone that hasn't really trained, studied, and did back testing.
After a liquidity sweep, price often reverses—plan for that.
Stick to the game plan: control risk, survive, and longevity follows.
Six years in—you finally grow into yourself as a trader.
Partial profits aren’t weakness—they pay the trader and de-risk the position.
Don’t measure yourself against others—that stunts your growth.
Income is your only working resource unless you add income streams.
Markets can become self-medication—don’t chase the dopamine hit.
FOMC and NFP share the same script: stop raid, then expansion.
The global interest rates are the fundamental driver that sets the tone for long-term macro price movement.
Play in the sandbox—build good habits on a demo account.
Dealers and or brokers do not set or control currency prices.
As long as you have internet and equity, you can eat—keep it simple and disciplined.
Equal highs and equal lows are the easiest liquidity to spot.
If it doesn’t set up in your window, it’s not your trade.
London close often marks the opposite end of the daily range.
In a bullish environment, expect a stop-run low before the expansion higher.
If you’re chasing every candle, you’re the liquidity.
If you’re pretending to be somebody you’re not, stop. This is your wake-up call.
Consider the negatives of forcing setups; impatience invites failure.
How much do I need to start trading? You answer that, but my canned response is two times your monthly income.
Retail sells ‘resistance’; smart money raids above it.
Study Monday to set up Tuesday; Tuesday is often the action day.
Target the buy stops above the relative equal high or original consolidation—this completes a market maker buy model.
Wednesday is the line in the sand: once price breaks the weekly open, it should expand away from it.
Taking profits is personal—you'll spend the rest of your life mastering that and never arriving at mastery.
A run through the high, retrace to OTE, then the real push—that’s the rhythm.
Banks target yesterday’s highs/lows. Your job: ride the run on liquidity.
Pressure from the real world makes you abandon rules and over-leverage.
Focus right away just trading the New York session—it’s going to be the easiest one.
A shallow push above the objective can precede the real expansion later in session.
Think completely opposite of retail.
Sometimes you're going to mess up, sometimes it's going to be wrong, and sometimes you're going to get stopped out—and it is what it is.
Nothing here is random; it’s the delivery of a weekly narrative that repeats.
This craft is a cruel lover if you don’t give it the time it demands.
The algorithm moves price when the time windows increase flows.
Your lowest timeframe is for entries; your mid timeframe is for management; your highest builds the premise.
The commitment of traders shows you a visual representation of what smart money is doing and how they’re positioned periodically.
Change the state of mind from impossible to I’m possible.
OTEs that align with kill zones are the A+ tickets.
Educators push the image of wealth quickly; it’s intoxicating when you need to make ends meet.
The Judas swing on a bullish week is the dip below the open that fuels the run higher.
What if you stop worrying about losing and focus on how to manage the money and the risk.
Write down what your life costs each month; make a budget.
Reduce risk as you get paid—manage the trader as much as the trade.
You have no idea what it feels like to grow an account from $10K to $50K to $100K until you do it.
Bias first; entries second.
After sweeping Thursday’s high on Friday, expect a return into the weekly range.
Expect pullbacks to order blocks or optimal trade entry inside the kill zones.
You’ll grow your understanding as the characteristics repeat over and over again.
If we’re bullish, there’s a 70% chance the low of the week forms on Monday, Tuesday, or by Wednesday’s New York session.
Traders don’t push price; the algorithm does.
Expect distribution into buy stops above the original consolidation in a buy model.

When I refer to power 3 what I'm referring to is the three components that make up generic price action: the accumulation phase, a manipulation stage, and then an arranged expansion and then a distribution.
If you can’t succeed on demo, you won’t succeed live.
Consider one percent per setup—that means one percent of your total account equity—and gradually working your way up to 2 percent if this meets your risk tolerance.
You want the holy grail? This is it: risk control.
Go into the charts looking to disprove what I’m saying—and you’re going to shock yourself.
Don’t be a slave to image.
Always view TradingView through the lens of New York time, wherever you live.
After weekly objectives are met early, expect consolidation or deeper retracement.
Bias = daily chart. Liquidity targets = hourly chart.
If you’re developing, stand aside on FOMC—the whipsaw will paralyze you.
Don’t quit—study, practice, and let time unlock understanding.
While you develop and practice in your demo account, it's important for you to implement strict risk controls.
Trust yourself; don’t outsource risk decisions to strangers.
Before strong directional moves, opposing stops are taken, then price is allowed to deliver.
Don’t let the market steal your life.
Cut exposure when you’re in drawdown; that’s your staying power.
What’s your routine—daily and weekly—and how do you handle drawdown?
Study the relationship of time and price; time comes first.
When a level is swept, ask “where is the opposing liquidity?” and aim there.
Don’t tell friends and family about your trades; protect your mindset.
Central banks are the producer of currency prices and are the market maker.
Settle on one trade setup initially.
If a day closes down in an up-bias, I’m stalking the next OTE long.
Don’t obsess over the exact top; catch the meat of the move and move on.
It's important not to try to swing for homeruns or take larger risk to try to grow your account faster—it's not necessary, it's reckless.
Three entry tools matter: stop runs, order blocks, and optimal trade entry.
Put your faith in time and price, not indicators.
Backtesting and studying old data makes every successful trader better.
SMT: you only consider using it when a key level should be influencing price.
Price won’t blast from every swept low—timing matters.
Practice in demo until the outcome no longer shakes you.
Be an independent thinking trader—not a codependent one.
London and New York kill zones frame the highest-probability entries.
Backtest day of week and time of day—those windows frame the highest-probability entries.
Let the Sunday open frame your bias; let Tuesday/Wednesday define your entry.
You have to have rules: when should I do something, when should I expect a setup to form?
Currency prices are 100% controlled and manipulated by central banks.
Trade soberly: target the least monthly end for a few months.
SMT is not a timing tool; it’s a confirmation tool.
Experience is going to guide you on how many candles really make up a consolidation.
SMT is simply a divergence between closely correlated assets or markets.
Time first, then price—calendar and clock anchor the setup.
FOMC days are “seek & destroy”—they raid both sides before expanding.
A weekly bias isn’t a guarantee—it’s a wind at your back. You still manage risk.
Manage your family time and schedule it—no markets, no charts, no Twitter.
These markets are vampires—they will suck every drop and the marrow in your bones if you give it to them.
Avoid system hopping.
Weather series of consecutive losses; every trader suffers drawdown.
We don’t care where the week closes—only where volatility mostly sends price.
Day trading isn’t every-day trading. Skip days without your setup.
You can carve out income with this—riches aren’t the goal; consistency is.
Lower your expenses and start preparing to think like a business owner.
Avoid large risk for large wins.
Above the weekly open is where smart money distributes when the higher time frame is bearish.
Protect your rules; they protect your account.
Practice every single day, keep a backlog, and study it on the weekends.
Identify what negates your idea before you even put the trade on.
Many treat funded challenges like a lottery.
In a bullish week, buy at or below the opening price each day.
Be honest in back testing—poor expectations create backwards results.
Don't seek the approval from others.
Trade the narrative: accumulation → manipulation → distribution to the next pool.
Don't think that you have to know everything right now—because you don't.
Many live above their income to put on a facade.
There’s no better way to learn than applying the model to a live chart and watching it unfold.
All boats rise with the tide—if euro rallies, reasonably expect pound to rally as well.
Proof of concept comes before live funds.
Determine your asset class—stick to that one asset class.
Be patient with your development.
If you need an indicator to believe it, you’ll miss the lesson: price tells you.
If you’re bullish, watch for short-term lows to be taken and then look to buy.
Learn risk management well—and make that your initial, very first thing to master.
Each day is one-fifth of the weekly range with repeating signatures.
The person you sit and stare at in the mirror—that person is your biggest enemy right now.
Central banks employ high-tech algorithms to deliver currency price feeds and they do not run on supply and demand.
Keep a study and trade schedule.
Stop trying to be perfect; aim to be consistent.
Over-leveraging because ‘it doesn’t hurt enough yet’ will wreck you.
Open, high, low, and close is the four best indicators you're ever going to find in price action—it's price.
Smart money accumulates below daily sell-side liquidity and distributes above weekly buy-side.
Price moves to where orders reside—above old highs and below old lows.
Build good habits and remove the opportunity to fall into bad habits.
Over leverage will impede your development and drastically decrease your chances of seeing responsible equity growth.
Your family is not going to understand what you're trying to do.
Ignore unprofitable traders’ advice on risk.
The ‘draw on liquidity’ is real: price seeks pools of stops.
Yesterday’s high isn’t ‘resistance’—it’s a magnet when bias is up.
Time and price theory blends the calendar clock with liquidity targets.
One trade should never be able to wipe out the account.
It may seem impossible right now, but I assure you it is possible.
You cannot escape it—you're going to lose money, you're going to lose on trades, and there's no reason to worry about it.
Take the loss, go home for the day, and see what happens tomorrow.
Central banks are not following retail indicators or flawed retail logic.
Relative equal highs and lows are liquidity, not support or resistance.
Young folks—control the urge to chase immediate wealth.
Reward yourself when you do it right, and when you do it wrong give yourself permission to be wrong.
Before directionally driven moves, opposing stops are taken and then price is allowed to deliver.
Stick to the method and reduce risk after losses.
Use funded accounts to seed your own retail account.
Rules first, entries second; without structure you’re just gambling.
Late in the week, probability favors retracement over continuation once objectives are met.
Smart money buys sell stops and sells to buy stops.
Momentum that starts on the daily tends to persist 2–5 days.
It cannot see your particular stop; the broker can, but the delivery algorithm cannot.
